questions.text: Sunray appearance on X-ray is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Osteogenic sarcoma (Osteosarcoma). The sunray (sunburst) appearance on X-ray is a characteristic feature of osteosarcoma, a highly malignant bone tumor that typically affects metaphyses of long bones (e.g., distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus) in adolescents and young adults. The sunburst pattern occurs due to aggressive periosteal reaction, where tumor bone spicules radiate outward in a perpendicular fashion from the cortex. This is caused by rapid tumor growth, which lifts the periosteum and produces new bone in a radiating pattern. Additionally, Codman’s triangle (periosteal elevation) is another radiographic sign commonly seen in osteosarcoma. Incorrect Options: B. Ewing's sarcoma Ewing’s sarcoma more commonly presents with an onion-skin (lamellated) periosteal reaction, not a sunburst pattern. It arises from the diaphysis of long bones and is associated with 11:22 translocation (EWS-FLI1 fusion gene). C. Multiple myeloma Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy that produces osteolytic punched-out lesions rather than periosteal reactions like the sunburst pattern. D. Osteoclastoma (Giant Cell Tumor) Osteoclastoma (Giant Cell Tumor, GCT) typically affects the epiphysis of long bones and appears as a soap-bubble lytic lesion on X-ray rather than a sunburst pattern.

questions.text: Safest light used in darkroom in an X-ray . department is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Red. In an X-ray department darkroom, safelight selection is critical to prevent film fogging while maintaining sufficient illumination for handling X-ray films. The safest light used is red because: Red light has the longest wavelength in the visible spectrum, which means it has the least energy and is least likely to expose or damage the X-ray film. It is commonly used in darkrooms with orthochromatic film, which is insensitive to red light but sensitive to blue and green light. Proper safelight conditions ensure that films can be processed without unintended exposure or degradation. Incorrect Options: A. Dull white White light contains all wavelengths, including blue and green, which are highly sensitive to X-ray films and would fog the film immediately. B. Blue Blue light has a shorter wavelength and higher energy, making it more likely to affect X-ray film exposure. Most X-ray films are blue-sensitive, so blue light is not safe in a darkroom. C. Green Green light is used in some film-screen combinations (green-sensitive films) but is not the safest choice. Green-sensitive films require red safelight, as green light can still expose the film

questions.text: X-ray was discovered by Roentgen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1895. X-rays were discovered by Wilhelm Conrad Roentgen on November 8, 1895. While experimenting with cathode rays in a Crookes tube, he noticed that an unknown type of radiation could penetrate opaque materials and cast shadows on a fluorescent screen. Since he did not know the nature of these rays, he called them "X-rays", where "X" denotes the unknown. For his groundbreaking discovery, Roentgen was awarded the first-ever Nobel Prize in Physics in 1901. Incorrect Options: A. 1886 No significant discovery related to X-rays occurred in 1886. However, earlier work by Philipp Lenard and Heinrich Hertz on cathode rays laid the foundation for Roentgen's discovery. B. 1902 By 1902, X-rays were already widely used in medicine and industry, and Roentgen had received his Nobel Prize (1901). D. 1907 X-ray technology had already advanced significantly by 1907, including the development of early X-ray tubes and diagnostic applications.

questions.text: In PA view of X-ray chest, right border of the heart is formed by all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Left atrial appendage, as it does not contribute to the right border of the heart in a PA (posteroanterior) chest X-ray. Anatomy of the Right Border of the Heart in PA View: In a PA chest X-ray, the right heart border is formed by structures located on the right side of the mediastinum, which include: Superior vena cava (SVC) - Forms the uppermost part of the right heart border. Right atrium (RA) - Forms the majority of the right heart border. Inferior vena cava (IVC) - Seen at the lower right portion, just above the diaphragm. Thus, options A (SVC), B (IVC), and C (Right atrium) are correct because they contribute to the right heart border. The left atrial appendage (LAA) is part of the left atrium, which is located posteriorly in the mediastinum. In a PA chest X-ray, the left atrial appendage contributes to the left heart border, not the right border.

questions.text: Minimal pleural effusion is best viewed in which position?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lateral decubitus positioning is the best method to detect minimal pleural effusion on X-ray. In this position, the patient lies on the side of the suspected effusion, allowing free-flowing fluid to shift and form a layer along the dependent chest wall. This technique can detect as little as 10-15 mL of pleural fluid, making it the most sensitive radiographic method for identifying small effusions. Incorrect Options: B. Full inspiration erect In an erect position, gravity causes pleural fluid to accumulate in the costophrenic angles, making larger effusions visible. However, small pleural effusions (<75 mL) may remain undetected, as they spread thinly along the pleural surface. C. Supine In the supine position, pleural fluid spreads evenly over the posterior pleural space, leading to a diffuse haziness or "veil-like" opacity rather than a clearly defined meniscus. Minimal effusions are easily missed in this view. D. Full expiration erect Expiration reduces lung volume, which may enhance detection of pneumothorax but does not improve visualization of minimal pleural effusion. The fluid remains in the dependent area, and smaller amounts may still be difficult to detect.

choices.text: Loss of plane between soft tissue and muscle

questions.text: Earliest radiological change to appear in case of acute osteomyelitis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Loss of plane between soft tissue and muscle. In acute osteomyelitis, the earliest radiological change is soft tissue swelling, which appears within 24-48 hours of infection. This is seen as a loss of fat planes between muscles and soft tissues on X-ray. The infection initially affects the bone marrow and adjacent soft tissues, leading to inflammatory edema and swelling, which is detectable before bone changes become apparent. Incorrect Options: A. Periosteal reaction Periosteal reaction occurs later (7-10 days after infection onset) due to subperiosteal pus accumulation. It appears as elevation of the periosteum on radiographs. C. Sequestrum formation Sequestrum (a necrotic bone fragment separated from healthy bone) is a chronic feature of osteomyelitis. It usually develops after weeks to months and is seen in chronic osteomyelitis rather than the acute phase. D. Bony sclerosis Bony sclerosis represents a late response of bone to infection, appearing after several weeks to months as part of the chronic healing process. It is not an early sign of acute osteomyelitis.

choices.text: Speed of electrons in X-ray tube

questions.text: Speed of X-ray is equal to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Speed of light. X-rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation, just like visible light, radio waves, and gamma rays. All electromagnetic waves, including X-rays, travel at the speed of light (c), which is approximately 3 × 108 meters per second (m/s) in a vacuum. The speed of X-rays is not dependent on their energy, frequency, or wavelength; it remains constant in a vacuum. Incorrect Options: B. Speed of electrons in the X-ray tube Inside an X-ray tube, electrons are accelerated toward the tungsten target by a high voltage (kVp), but their speed is much lower than the speed of light. The speed of these electrons depends on the applied voltage but is not equal to the speed of X-rays. C. Tube voltage Tube voltage (measured in kilovolts, kVp) determines the energy and penetrating power of X-rays, but it does not influence their speed. Higher tube voltage increases X-ray energy (shorter wavelength, higher frequency) but not their velocity. D. All of the above Only the speed of light is correct; the speed of electrons and tube voltage do not determine the speed of X-rays.

questions.text: Contrast in X-rays is dependent on:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) KV (Kilovoltage). Contrast in X-rays is primarily dependent on the kilovoltage (KV) because it determines the penetrating power of the X-ray beam. Higher KV - Produces lower contrast (more shades of gray), as it results in greater penetration and reduces the difference between tissues. Lower KV - Produces higher contrast (fewer shades of gray), as it increases the difference in attenuation between tissues. Incorrect Options: (B) rnA (likely a typo for mA - milliamperes): Controls the quantity (intensity) of X-rays, affecting image brightness but not contrast. (C) Duration of exposure: Affects image density and motion blur but not contrast. (D) Distance between source and object: Affects image magnification and sharpness, but not the inherent contrast.

questions.text: Hilar markings in a normal chest X-ray is formed by all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lower lobe veins. Hilar markings on a normal chest X-ray are primarily formed by the pulmonary vasculature and bronchi, which include: These are located more peripherally and do not significantly contribute to the hilar markings. Incorrect Options: Pulmonary arteries (A) – Major contributors to hilar markings, as they branch from the main pulmonary trunk. Bronchi (B) – Visible as air-filled structures surrounded by soft tissue. Upper lobe veins (C) – Contribute to the markings as part of the pulmonary venous circulation.

questions.text: Angle of tracheal bifurcation is increased in enlargement of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Left atrium. The angle of tracheal bifurcation (also known as the carinal angle) is normally about 60–75 degrees. This angle can increase due to conditions that cause widening of the mediastinum or displacement of the bronchi. Left atrial enlargement (e.g., in mitral valve disease) causes posterior displacement of the left main bronchus, leading to an increased carinal angle. This is commonly seen in conditions like mitral stenosis or left heart failure, where increased pressure in the left atrium leads to its dilation. Incorrect Options: (A) Right ventricle enlargement – Typically causes upward displacement of the cardiac silhouette but does not significantly affect the carinal angle. (B) Left ventricle enlargement – Expands more downward and laterally rather than affecting the tracheal bifurcation. (C) Right atrium enlargement – Primarily affects the right heart border on a chest X-ray, not the tracheal bifurcation.

questions.text: Centenary year for X-ray is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1995. X-rays were discovered by Wilhelm Conrad Roentgen on November 8, 1895. To mark the 100th anniversary (centenary year) of this groundbreaking discovery, the year 1995 was celebrated as the centenary year of X-rays. Incorrect Options: 1999 (B), 1997 (C), 2001 (D)- do not correspond to the 100-year anniversary of the discovery of X-rays.

questions.text: Use of filters result in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Beam of greater intensity. Filters in X-ray machines are used to remove low-energy (soft) X-rays from the beam before they reach the patient. These low-energy X-rays contribute to patient dose without improving image quality. By removing these weaker photons, the overall beam becomes: More penetrating (higher average energy) More intense (higher energy per photon) Incorrect Options: (A) Softer beam radiation – Incorrect, because filters remove soft (low-energy) X-rays, making the beam harder (more penetrating). (B) Wider beam coverage – Incorrect, as filters do not change the beam's coverage but only its energy distribution. (C) Less penetrating beam – Incorrect, because filtering increases penetration by removing low-energy rays.

questions.text: Use of a cone results in films of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Higher contrast. A cone is a beam-restricting device used in X-ray imaging to collimate (limit) the X-ray beam to a specific area, reducing scatter radiation. Less scatter radiation leads to higher image contrast, as scatter contributes to fogging and reduces the ability to distinguish between different densities. Incorrect Options: (B) Low contrast –, because reducing scatter increases contrast, not decreases it. (C) Less motion – as a cone does not affect patient or equipment motion. (D) Long scale contrast – because a long scale contrast means more shades of gray (low contrast), whereas a cone results in short scale contrast (higher contrast).

questions.text: "Target material" which produces X-rays in a diagnostic X-rays tube is made of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tungsten. The target material in a diagnostic X-ray tube is typically made of tungsten (W) due to its ideal physical properties: High atomic number (Z = 74): A higher atomic number increases X-ray production efficiency. High melting point (~3,422°C or 6,192°F): Allows it to withstand intense heat generated during X-ray production. Good thermal conductivity: Helps dissipate heat effectively, preventing damage to the anode. Incorrect Options: (A) Lead: Used for radiation shielding but not as a target material. (C) Cobalt: Used in radiation therapy (Cobalt-60) but not in X-ray tubes. (D) Copper: Used as a backing material for the anode but not as the primary target.

questions.text: The photosensitive material used in X-rays films consist of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Silver bromide. The photosensitive material in X-ray films is primarily silver bromide (AgBr), which is a key component of the film's emulsion layer. Silver bromide is light-sensitive, meaning it reacts to X-ray and light exposure to form a latent image, which is then developed into a visible radiograph. Incorrect Options: (A) Cellulose: Used as a film base (historically cellulose nitrate or acetate) but not as a photosensitive material. (C) Zinc sulphide: Used in fluoroscopy screens, not in X-ray film. (D) Cadmium tungstate: A phosphor used in intensifying screens but not in X-ray film.

questions.text: X-ray films are least sensitive to which coloured light?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Red. X-ray films are traditionally most sensitive to shorter wavelengths of visible light, particularly blue and violet light, because: Silver halide crystals (e.g., silver bromide) are highly sensitive to blue and violet light. Red light has the longest wavelength and lowest energy, making X-ray films least sensitive to it. Incorrect Options: (A) Violet – High energy, strongly affects X-ray films. (B) Blue – Also highly affects X-ray films, which is why blue-sensitive films exist. (C) Yellow – Moderate effect but more than red light.

questions.text: Unit of one dose of radiation absorbed is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gray (Gy). The Gray (Gy) is the SI unit of absorbed radiation dose, which measures the amount of radiation energy absorbed per kilogram of tissue. 1 Gray (Gy) = 1 joule of radiation energy absorbed per kilogram of matter (J/kg). Incorrect Options: (B) Roentgen (R): Measures exposure to X-rays and gamma rays in air, not the absorbed dose in tissue. (C) Curie (Ci): Measures the radioactivity of a substance (decay rate), not the absorbed dose. (D) Becquerel (Bq): The SI unit of radioactivity, measuring decay per second, not absorbed dose

questions.text: Dead bone on an X-ray looks:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dead bone (also known as sequestrum) appears more radiopaque on an X-ray because: It is densely mineralized and lacks the normal bone turnover seen in living bone. Since it is not resorbed or remodeled, it retains its calcium content, making it appear whiter (more radiopaque) than the surrounding bone. Incorrect Options: (B) Radiolucent – as radiolucency indicates less density (e.g., infection, bone loss), but dead bone remains dense. (C) Less radiopaque – sequestrum is actually more radiopaque. (D) Is not seen at all – dead bone is clearly visible on X-rays due to its increased density.

questions.text: X-ray machine is kept at a distance of 6 feet from the photographic plate to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Prevent magnification. The distance between the X-ray source and the image receptor (photographic plate) is called the Source-to-Image Distance (SID). A standard distance of 6 feet (or more) is used to reduce geometric magnification and image distortion. If the X-ray tube is too close, the X-ray beams diverge more, causing magnification and blurring of the image. Increasing the distance helps produce a more accurate representation of the anatomical structures. Incorrect Options: (A) Magnify the image – because increasing distance actually reduces magnification. (C) Enhance contrast – as contrast is mainly influenced by KV, beam filtration, and scatter reduction, not distance. (D) None – because maintaining an appropriate distance is crucial for image accuracy.

questions.text: Target material used for generating X-rays:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tungsten. The target material in an X-ray tube is typically tungsten (W) because of its ideal properties: High atomic number (Z = 74): A higher atomic number increases the efficiency of X-ray production. High melting point (~3,422°C or 6,192°F): Allows it to withstand the extreme heat generated during X-ray production. Good thermal conductivity: Helps dissipate heat efficiently, preventing damage to the anode. Incorrect Options: (B) Cobalt: Used in radiation therapy (Cobalt-60) but not in X-ray tubes. (C) Cadmium: Used in nuclear control rods, not in X-ray production. (D) Palladium: Used in dental and jewelry applications, but not for generating X-rays.

questions.text: Maximum penetration is seen with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ? (gamma) particles. Penetration ability of radiation depends on its energy and mass: Gamma (?) rays have the highest penetration power because: They are electromagnetic waves (not particles) with no mass or charge. They can pass through most materials, requiring thick lead or concrete for shielding. Incorrect Options: (A) Alpha (?) particles – Lowest penetration (stopped by paper or skin) because they are large and positively charged. (B) Beta (?) particles – Moderate penetration (stopped by plastic or aluminum) but less than gamma rays. (D) Electron beam – Similar to beta particles but does not penetrate as much as gamma rays.

questions.text: OnX-ray,right borderofthemediastinum is formed by all the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Right ventricle. Right ventricle does NOT form the right mediastinal border. The right ventricle is an anterior structure and primarily contributes to the cardiac silhouette, not the mediastinal border. On a chest X-ray (CXR), the right border of the mediastinum is formed by the following structures: (A) Superior vena cava (SVC): Forms the upper portion of the right mediastinal border. (B) Right atrium: Forms the lower portion of the right mediastinal border. (D) Right brachiocephalic vein: Contributes to the upper right mediastinal contour.

questions.text: Radiological investigation in females of reproductive age should be restricted to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) First 10 days of the menstrual cycle. In females of reproductive age, radiological investigations involving ionizing radiation (such as X-rays, CT scans) should be restricted to the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle to minimize the risk of radiation exposure to an early pregnancy. This is known as the "10-day rule," which recommends that elective radiological procedures be performed during the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle (starting from day 1 of menstruation) when the probability of pregnancy is extremely low. If a woman is pregnant and exposed to radiation, particularly during organogenesis (weeks 3–8), there is a risk of fetal malformations, growth restriction, or even pregnancy loss. By scheduling imaging in the first 10 days, the risk of exposing a developing embryo to harmful radiation is significantly reduced. Incorrect Options: (B) Last 10 days of the menstrual cycle – Incorrect because this phase is the luteal phase, where fertilization may have already occurred, and implantation might take place. Performing radiological investigations during this period increases the risk of unknowingly exposing an early pregnancy to radiation, which could potentially cause developmental issues. (C) 10-20th day of the menstrual cycle – Incorrect because this timeframe includes ovulation (around day 14), which is the period when a woman is most likely to conceive. If conception occurs, early embryonic development begins within days, and radiation exposure during this critical phase can increase the risk of birth defects or miscarriage. (D) Period of menstruation – While menstruation itself is part of the first 10 days of the cycle, scheduling imaging during menstruation is unnecessary when it can be safely performed at any point within the first 10 days. Some women may also find undergoing radiological procedures during menstruation uncomfortable.

questions.text: The right side of mediastinum shadow is not formed by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Right ventricle. The right ventricle is an anterior structure of the heart and does not contribute to the right mediastinal border seen on a chest X-ray. Instead, the right mediastinal shadow is primarily formed by the superior vena cava, right innominate (brachiocephalic) vein, and the right atrium, which all lie more laterally or medially compared to the right ventricle. Incorrect Options: (A) Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava forms a major part of the upper right mediastinal border. Its prominent vertical course along the right side of the mediastinum makes it clearly visible on chest radiographs. (B) Right innominate vein: The right innominate vein contributes to the formation of the right mediastinal border, especially at the upper aspect, by merging with the left innominate vein to form the superior vena cava. (C) Right atrium: The right atrium forms the lower portion of the right mediastinal border. It is a key component of the mediastinal silhouette, seen as part of the heart’s outline on a chest X-ray.

questions.text: Increased radiolucency of one sided hemithorax may be caused by all the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Expiratory film. An expiratory film is not a cause of increased radiolucency in one hemithorax. In fact, during expiration, the lung volumes decrease as the air is expelled, leading to a relatively denser (more radiopaque) appearance. Therefore, an expiratory film would not produce the appearance of a hyperlucent (overly dark) hemithorax. Incorrect Options: (A) Obstructive emphysema: This condition causes air trapping and overinflation of the affected lung. The excess air increases radiolucency, making the lung appear darker on the X-ray. Thus, obstructive emphysema is a known cause of unilateral increased radiolucency. (B) Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space. The presence of air, which is radiolucent, results in a darker appearance of the affected hemithorax on the radiograph. This is a classic cause of increased radiolucency. (D) Rotation: Patient rotation during the X-ray can create asymmetry in the appearance of the lung fields. Rotation may cause one hemithorax to seem more radiolucent due to changes in the projected thickness of the chest wall and lung tissues, potentially mimicking increased radiolucency.

questions.text: Superior orbital fissure best view is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Caldwell. The Caldwell view, also known as the occipitofrontal projection, is the best radiographic projection to visualize the superior orbital fissure. This view is obtained with the patient's forehead and nose against the film and the X-ray beam angled 15 degrees caudally. Such angulation provides a clear and unobstructed image of the orbital margins, particularly the orbital roof and apex, where the superior orbital fissure is located. This makes the Caldwell view optimal for evaluating bony structures of the orbit. Incorrect Options: (A) Plain AP view: A plain anteroposterior view does not offer the necessary angulation to clearly demonstrate the superior orbital fissure. The direct AP projection can result in superimposition of orbital structures, which may obscure critical details, including the superior orbital fissure. (C) Townes view: The Townes view is not a standard projection used for detailed orbital imaging. It does not provide the proper orientation or angulation required to specifically highlight the superior orbital fissure, making it less suitable than the Caldwell view. (D) Basal view: The basal view (or submentovertex view) is primarily used to evaluate the cranial base and the structures at the bottom of the skull. It does not project the orbital apex or the superior orbital fissure as clearly as the Caldwell view, and therefore is not ideal for this purpose.

choices.text: A metastatic tumour in the bone

questions.text: "Sunray appearance" on X-rays is suggestive of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) An osteogenic sarcoma. Osteogenic sarcoma, also known as osteosarcoma, is a primary malignant bone tumor that often produces a "sunray" or "sunburst" pattern on X-rays. This appearance results from aggressive periosteal reaction where new bone is produced in a radiating, spiculated pattern around the tumor, mimicking rays emanating from the sun. The characteristic periosteal reaction is a key diagnostic clue in identifying osteogenic sarcoma. Incorrect Options: (A) A chondrosarcoma: Chondrosarcoma typically shows calcifications in a chondroid matrix on X-rays rather than a sunray appearance. Its radiographic features usually include ring-and-arc calcifications and a lobulated mass, not the aggressive periosteal reaction seen in osteosarcoma. (B) A metastatic tumour in the bone: Metastatic lesions in bone generally appear as lytic or blastic lesions depending on the primary source, but they do not produce a sunray pattern. The pattern of bone destruction or sclerosis in metastases is usually more irregular and less structured compared to the spiculated periosteal reaction of osteogenic sarcoma. (D) An Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is known for its "onion skin" periosteal reaction due to layered new bone formation. This pattern is distinctly different from the sunray appearance, which is characterized by radiating bone spicules associated with osteogenic sarcoma.

questions.text: All of them use non-ionizing radiation, except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Radiography. Radiography uses X-rays, which are a form of ionizing radiation. Ionizing radiation carries enough energy to remove tightly bound electrons from atoms, which can lead to molecular changes and potential tissue damage. This characteristic distinguishes radiography from the other imaging modalities listed, all of which utilize non-ionizing radiation. In radiography, the energy of X-rays is harnessed to create images of internal structures, but due to the nature of ionizing radiation, strict safety protocols are essential. Incorrect Options: (A) Ultrasonography: Ultrasonography uses high-frequency sound waves that are non-ionizing. These sound waves are reflected off tissues to create an image, posing no risk of ionization or associated tissue damage. (B) Thermography: Thermography relies on infrared radiation, which is non-ionizing. It measures the heat emitted by the body to produce images, without the risks associated with ionizing radiation. (C) MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) utilizes strong magnetic fields and radiofrequency pulses. Both of these forms of energy are non-ionizing, making MRI a safe imaging modality in terms of radiation exposure.

questions.text: Which one of the following has the maximum ionization potential?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Helium ion. Helium ions, which are essentially alpha particles, have a high mass and carry a double positive charge. This combination gives them a high linear energy transfer (LET), meaning they deposit a large amount of energy over a very short distance as they pass through matter. This dense ionization track makes helium ions the most effective in causing ionization, thereby exhibiting the maximum ionization potential among the options provided. Incorrect Options: (A) Electron: Electrons are very light and carry a single negative charge. They produce less dense ionization tracks because they transfer energy more sparsely as they traverse matter, resulting in a lower ionization potential compared to helium ions. (B) Proton: Protons are heavier than electrons and carry a positive charge, which gives them a higher ionization potential than electrons. However, being singly charged, they do not deposit energy as densely as helium ions, making their ionization potential lower than that of helium ions. (D) Gamma (?)-Photon: Gamma photons are uncharged and interact with matter indirectly (via mechanisms such as the photoelectric effect or Compton scattering). They deposit energy less directly and less densely, resulting in the lowest ionization potential compared to charged particles.

questions.text: Patient with history of tachyarrhythmias is on implantable cardioverler defibrilla­ tor. He develops shock. Best method to know the position and integrity of lCD is to do:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Plain radiograph. In a patient with an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) who develops shock, a plain radiograph (chest X-ray) is the most efficient and practical method to assess the position and integrity of the ICD. Plain radiography provides clear images of the ICD generator and leads, allowing for the identification of any malposition, lead fractures, or disconnections. It is readily available, quick to perform, and safe for patients with implanted devices. Incorrect Options: (A) Contrast CT: Although CT can offer detailed cross-sectional images, the presence of metal in the ICD leads to significant artifact, which may obscure critical details. Additionally, CT involves higher radiation doses and the use of contrast, making it less ideal for routine assessment of ICD position. (B) MRI: MRI is generally contraindicated in patients with ICDs because the strong magnetic fields can interfere with the device's function and potentially cause harm. Even if an MRI-compatible ICD is in place, MRI is not the first-line investigation for evaluating device integrity. (C) Ultrasound: Ultrasound is not effective in visualizing the metallic components of an ICD. Its utility is limited to soft tissue evaluation, and it does not provide the necessary detail to assess the position or integrity of the ICD leads and generator.

questions.text: Difference between light and X-ray:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Energy. The primary difference between visible light and X-rays lies in the energy of their photons. X-rays have a much higher frequency than visible light, which according to the equation E = hf (where E is energy, h is Planck's constant, and f is frequency), means they carry significantly more energy. This high energy enables X-rays to penetrate materials that visible light cannot, which is why they are used in medical imaging and other applications where deep tissue visualization is required. Incorrect Options: (B) Mass: Both visible light and X-rays are forms of electromagnetic radiation and are composed of photons, which are massless. Therefore, mass is not a distinguishing factor. (C) Speed: In a vacuum, both visible light and X-rays travel at the same speed—the speed of light, approximately 3 × 10^8 m/s. Hence, speed does not differentiate them. (D) Type of wave: Both visible light and X-rays are electromagnetic waves. They share the same basic nature as waves, even though they differ in wavelength and frequency. Thus, the type of wave is the same for both

choices.text: Left dome of diaphragm higher than the right
Pulmonary vessels behind heart are not visible
Bowel between liver and right hemidiaphragm is abnormal
Rotation causes a change in translucency of the lungs

questions.text: True about PA chest X-ray view:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Left hemidiaphragm lower due to heart; pulmonary artery forms major part of hilum not periphery. Bowel in between liver and right hemidiaphragm is normal (Chiladati sign) Rotation causes change in translucency of hemithorax.
